item.title: Revved-Up Polish Assets at Risk With Nationalist Winning Ballot
item.description: Investors in Polish stocks and bonds — among the world’s stand-out performers of 2025 — are on edge as a nationalist won the presidential election, dealing a blow to the pro-European government.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko, Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: Poll workers empty the ballot boxes at a primary school before they are counted during the second round of the presidential elections in Gdansk, on June 1, 2025. Photo Mateusz SLODKOWSKI / AFP/Getty Images

item.title: At Least 21 Palestinians Killed Heading to Gaza Aid Hub, Hospital Says
item.description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — At least 31 people were killed and over 170 were wounded Sunday as large crowds were on their way to receive food in the Gaza Strip, health officials and witnesses said. Witnesses said Israeli forces fired toward the crowds just before dawn around a kilometer (about 1,100 yards) from an aid site run by an Israeli-backed foundation.

media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians ferry bags of food aid after storming a World Food Programme warehouse in Deir el-Balah in the central Gaza Strip on May 28 Photo by Eyad BABA/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: EYAD BABA/AFP

item.title: Taiwan Warns of Rise in Chinese Military Activity Around Region
item.description: Taiwan said China escalated military pressure around the region in May, deploying dozens of warships and government vessels daily in what it described as an extreme pressure campaign.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Wang

media:content.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers move in formation during Taiwanese President William Lai's (Lai Ching-te) visit to a military base, in Kaohsiung, Taiwan.

item.title: Pro-Trump Nationalist Wins Poland’s Presidential Election
item.description: A nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump won Poland’s presidential election, defeating the centrist mayor of Warsaw in a blow to the country’s pro-European Union government.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa, Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, center, with his wife Marta and their children during an election night rally in Warsaw, Poland, on June 1, 2025.

item.title: China Accuses US of Violating Trade Deal, Vows Firm Response
item.description: China accused the US of violating their recent trade deal and vowed to take measures to defend its interests, dimming the prospect of an immediate leadership call that Donald Trump wants to have to further bilateral talks.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Reportedly Mulls Return to US This Week
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is considering returning to the US for another round of trade negotiations this week as expectations mount for a deal as early as this month.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Chile Presidential Polls Show Matthei With Slight Lead Over Kast
item.description: Chile center-right presidential candidate Evelyn Matthei held a small lead over more conservative contender Jose Antonio Kast atop two polls published on Sunday, reflecting an open race for the nation’s top job.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Evelyn Matthei Photographer: Cristobal Olivares/Bloomberg

item.title: Southeast Asia Joins Europe’s Calls to Defend Subsea Cables
item.description: Defense officials from Europe and Southeast Asia called for stronger collaboration to protect the global network of subsea cables as concerns grow over threats to this vital infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Underwater Cable On Sea Floor Source: Mint Images/Mint Images/Getty Images

item.title: Hegseth Wins Praise But Asia Still Has Strong Doubts About Trump
item.description: After US military allies in Europe were torched by Vice President JD Vance in March over military spending, free speech and the war in Ukraine, America’s partners in Asia warily awaited Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s arrival at a security conference in Singapore.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Philip Heijmans, Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth speaks during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on May 31.

item.title: South Korea’s Election Frontrunner Still Leaves Many Unconvinced
item.description: Lee Jae-myung is still the frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential race, but what once looked like a landslide victory has turned into a much closer contest.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung arrives for a campaign event in Incheon.

item.title: US Calls on Australia to Boost Defense Spending to 3.5% of GDP
item.description: US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth has asked Australia to dramatically raise its military spending to 3.5% of gross domestic product “as soon as possible,” according to an official readout of his meeting with Australia’s Defence Minister Richard Marles.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Richard Marles speaks during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on May 31.

item.title: South Korea Crypto Industry to Gain No Matter Who Wins Election
item.description: No matter who clinches South Korea’s presidential election this week, one outcome is certain: the country’s crypto industry is poised to win.
item.dc:creator: Sidhartha Shukla

media:content.media:description: Inside of Total crypto mining facility in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, on Thursday, March 28, 2024. Crypto-linked investments have been a popular choice for South Koreans.

item.title: UK to Build More Attack Submarines in ‘Message to Moscow’
item.description: The UK intends to send a “message to Moscow” with plans to expand its fleet of attack submarines and invest in its nuclear deterrent as part of a new defense strategy to head off the threat posed by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: The HMS Artful, an Astute Class nuclear-powered submarine, at His Majesty’s Naval Base Clyde in Faslane, Scotland, on March 4.

item.title: Sudan’s Army-Backed Prime Minister Poised to Form New Government
item.description: Sudan’s army-appointed Prime Minister Kamil Idris dissolved the government in preparation to form a new cabinet, almost two weeks after he was announced as the war-torn country’s first premier in more than three years.
item.dc:creator: Sherif Tarek

media:content.media:description: Members of the Sudanese Armed Forces depart from the Presidential Palace in Khartoum, Sudan, on March 26, 2025.

item.title: Chile’s Boric Vows to Rely Less on Israel, Citing Gaza Violence
item.description: Chile President Gabriel Boric vowed to diversify his nation’s defense ties to depend less on Israel, issuing a scathing rebuke over violence in Gaza during his annual State of the Nation address on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Gabriel Boric speaks during a State of the Nation annual address at the National Congress in Valparaiso, Chile on June 1, 2025. Photographer: Francesco Degasperi/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Pro-EU Mayor Takes Slim Lead in Poland Vote, Exit Polls Show
item.description: The centrist mayor of Warsaw took a slim lead in Poland’s presidential election over a nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump, giving a boost to the country’s pro-European Union government, exit polls show.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa, Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski and his wife Malgorzata Trzaskowska, during an election night rally in Warsaw, Poland, on Sunday, June 1, 2025.

item.title: Graham Aims for Tough New Russia Sanctions Ahead of G-7 Summit
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, a close ally of President Donald Trump, said he aims to have new sanctions imposed on Russia before the Group of Seven summit in late June.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Whitelaw

media:content.media:description: US Senators Lindsey Graham, right, and Richard Blumenthal speak during a press conference at Mykhailivska Square in Kyiv on May 30, 2025. Photographer: Tetiana Dzhafarova/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Carney Picks Canadian Pension Executive as Next Chief of Staff
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney is hiring an executive from one of Canada’s top pension fund managers to be his chief of staff.
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey Morgan

media:content.media:description: Marc-Andre Blanchard Photographer: Sajjad Hussain/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Pulls Nomination of Musk Ally Isaacman to Lead NASA
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would name a new nominee for NASA administrator, just days before billionaire Jared Isaacman, the current pick and a close ally of Elon Musk, was to face his planned Senate confirmation vote.
item.dc:creator: Loren Grush, Sana Pashankar

media:content.media:description: Jared Isaacman, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) nominee for US President Donald Trump, during a Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. President Donald Trump's nominee to run NASA will tell US senators the agency's priority will be to send US astronauts to Mars, while promoting a thriving space economy in orbit.

item.title: Slovak Leader Rules Out Support for Kazimir’s Return as Governor
item.description: Prime Minister Robert Fico will not support the reappointment of Peter Kazimir as head of Slovakia’s central bank, the Slovak leader said on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Robert Fico, Slovakia's prime minister, during the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in National Harbor, Maryland, US, on Friday, Feb. 21, 2025. The Conservative Political Action Conference launched in 1974 brings together conservative organizations, elected leaders, and activists.

item.title: UK Joins US, France in Backing Morocco Plan for West Sahara
item.description: The UK backed Morocco’s plan to administer the disputed territory of Western Sahara, in a historic shift mirroring moves by France and the US.
item.dc:creator: Souhail Karam

media:content.media:description: Camels roam next to wind turbines that will supply power to a desalination plant under construction in Dakhla in the disputed Western Sahara on May 26, 2025.

item.title: Bessent Says US Will Never Default as Congress Faces Endgame
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US “is never going to default” as the deadline for increasing the federal debt ceiling gets closer.
item.dc:creator: Tony Czuczka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Musk Denies Ketamine Use Following New York Times Report
item.description: Billionaire Elon Musk said that he is not using the drug ketamine, disputing a report by the New York Times that alleged extensive use of that and other drugs.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Chaves

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House on May 30. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico

item.title: Germany Plans Corporate Tax Breaks to Spur Investment, DPA Says
item.description: German Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil is planning a number of tax breaks for companies aimed at spurring investment and lifting the economy out of its long bout of stagnation, according to Deutsche Presse-Agentur.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: A Volkswagen ID.5 electric car displayed in the showroom at the Volkswagen AG factory in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. Volkswagen and other EV makers appear to be benefiting from consumers’ aversion to Tesla after Elon Musk became more involved in US President Donald Trump’s administration and supported far-right political movements in Europe, such as Germany’s AfD party.

item.title: UK Shifts War Footing To ‘Always-On’ Munitions Production
item.description: The UK will create an “always on” munitions production capacity to allow it to scale-up its defense industry when needed, as it increasingly shifts to a war footing with Russia’s assault on Ukraine showing little sign of ending.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Amedeo Goria

media:content.media:description: UK soldiers maneuver an anti-aircraft gun during the 'Allied Spirit25' US military and NATO training exercise in Hohenfels, Germany, on March 12.

item.title: Hegseth Reassures Asia Allies Unsettled by Trump: Balance of Power
item.description: Welcome to a special edition of Balance of Power, focusing on the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. Each weekday we bring you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Alberto Nardelli, Josh Xiao, Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth, US secretary of defense, gives a thumbs up during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, on Saturday, May 31, 2025. The conference runs through June 1. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Steel Tariffs ‘Economic Self Harm,’ Australian PM Says
item.description: Donald Trump’s decision to double steel tariffs on imports was “inappropriate” but it won’t impact Australia any more than it would other countries, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said.
item.dc:creator: Chelsea Mes

media:content.media:description: Scrap metal heated in a steel furnace at BlueScope Steel Ltd. Port Kembla steelworks in Port Kembla, Australia, on Friday, Feb. 9, 2024. The world's two biggest miners, BHP Group Ltd. and Rio Tinto Group, are teaming up in a bid to develop Australia's first electric-smelting furnace, in what could prove an important step toward slashing emissions in the steel-making process.

item.title: Hungary’s Top Court Strikes Down Police Ban on LGBTQ Gathering
item.description: Hungary’s top court struck down a police ban of a pro-LGBTQ gathering in Budapest, in a test of Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s escalating culture war before elections next year.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators march during the annual Pride parade in Budapest, Hungary, on Saturday, July 24, 2021. Brussels is threatening action over an LGBTQ law that could involve cutting funds to Budapest; Prime Minister Viktor Orban has proposed to put what he calls the protection of children against homosexual content to a referendum.

item.title: Bangladesh Charges Ex-PM Hasina With Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: Bangladeshi prosecutors officially charged former prime minister Sheikh Hasina and two senior officials with crimes against humanity for their alleged roles in violent crackdowns during the 2024 student-led uprising.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's prime minister, speaks during the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York, US, on Friday, Sept. 22, 2023. Global leaders descend upon midtown Manhattan this week for speeches, meetings and receptions, an annual migration to the United Nations meant to tackle the world's biggest problems.

item.title: Iran Says It’s Not After Nuclear Bombs as It Rejects IAEA Report
item.description: Iran criticized a new report by the UN nuclear watchdog accusing it of nuclear violations, claiming the agency is motivated by politics and reiterating it isn’t seeking atomic weapons.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: A picture taken on November 10, 2019, shows an Iranian flag in Iran's Bushehr nuclear power plant, during an official ceremony to kick-start works on a second reactor at the facility. - Bushehr is Iran's only nuclear power station and is currently running on imported fuel from Russia that is closely monitored by the UN's International Atomic Energy Agency. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP) (Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP
